articles.headline: Congress Ends 5-Year Standoff on Trade Deals in Rare Accord
articles.snippet: Approval of long-awaited free trade agreements with three countries offered a rare moment of bipartisan agreement in Washington.
articles.abstract: Approval of long-awaited free trade agreements with three countries offered a rare moment of bipartisan agreement in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress passed three long-awaited free trade agreements on Wednesday, ending a political standoff that has stretched across two presidencies. The move offered a rare moment of bipartisan accord at a time when Republicans and Democrats are bitterly divided over the role that government ought to play in reviving the sputtering economy.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Unlikely Turn for a Suspect in a Terror Plot
articles.snippet: Mansour J. Arbabsiar, suspected in an alleged Iranian plot to kill a Saudi diplomat in Washington, seems to have been more a stumbling opportunist than a calculating killer.
articles.abstract: Mansour J. Arbabsiar, suspected in an alleged Iranian plot to kill a Saudi diplomat in Washington, seems to have been more a stumbling opportunist than a calculating killer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His nickname was Scarface, the legacy of a brutal knife attack on a dark Houston street three decades ago that left his left cheek permanently marred. Friends and neighbors in Texas said that he could be gruff and intimidating, and that he often stood outside his house at night smoking and talking on his cellphone in a language they did not understand.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Laura Tillman

articles.headline: With Just Three 9s, Cain Refigured Math for Taxes
articles.snippet: Herman Cain’s 9-9-9 plan for taxes is getting intensive new scrutiny as Republicans continue to flirt with their candidates.
articles.abstract: Herman Cain’s 9-9-9 plan for taxes is getting intensive new scrutiny as Republicans continue to flirt with their candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a strategy session at 28,000 feet. Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate, and his advisers were on a campaign flight this summer between Atlanta and New Hampshire, tossing around policy ideas.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: On Bowery, Cultures Clash as the Shabby Meet the Shabby Chic
articles.snippet: On the floors above the cramped cubicles housing nine men, the Bowery House offers rooms to the young and stylish seeking a reminder of the area’s gritty past.
articles.abstract: On the floors above the cramped cubicles housing nine men, the Bowery House offers rooms to the young and stylish seeking a reminder of the area’s gritty past.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Bowery, on the second floor of an ancient flophouse, nine men pay less than $10 a night to sleep in cramped cubicles topped with chicken wire. Half the stalls in their shared bathroom are missing doors, and their halls are lined with spooky rows of empty cubicles whose last occupants either took off or died off.

articles.headline: In Strangers’ Glances at Family, Tensions Linger
articles.snippet: For one family, being mixed-race is not a defining issue, but outside the home, strangers gawk and make racist comments, in what has become part of life for many families like theirs.
articles.abstract: For one family, being mixed-race is not a defining issue, but outside the home, strangers gawk and make racist comments, in what has become part of life for many families like theirs.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOMS RIVER, N.J. — “How come she’s so white and you’re so dark?”

articles.headline: A Quest for Hybrid Companies That Profit, but Can Tap Charity
articles.snippet: More than 12 states have passed laws allowing companies to emphasize social benefits more than profit, bridging the gap between businesses and nonprofits.
articles.abstract: More than 12 states have passed laws allowing companies to emphasize social benefits more than profit, bridging the gap between businesses and nonprofits.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new type of company intended to put social goals ahead of making profits is taking root around the country, as more states adopt laws to bridge the divide between nonprofits and businesses.
